instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V42_S5: What is PP3V42_S5? PP3V42_S5 is not real. You have PP3V3_S5 which is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in a soft off state, and PP3V42_G3H which is a 3.42v power rail when the system is in a G3H mechanical off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message:
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Customer claims the board isn't water damaged.[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Gives a green light but won't spin the fan.[/FONT][/COLOR]


[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]I get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12.61[/FONT][/COLOR]


[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 4.89v[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 2.70 - 2.97v (unstable)[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.27[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.42[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>S5_PWRD</SIGNAL>: 3.4v[/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0v[/FONT][/COLOR]


Susing out <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>...
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]---[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<TRANSISTOR>Q7840</TRANSISTOR>[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin1: 2.68 - 2.89v (unstable)[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin3: 3.45 - 3.7 (unstable)[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin7: 4.89.[/FONT][/COLOR]



[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Testing <TRANSISTOR>Q7822</TRANSISTOR> I get;[/FONT][/COLOR]

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin 1: Gnd.[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin 2: 0.4v, 0.5v, 0.6v back to 0.4v.[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin 3: 3.2v, 3.6v, 3.7v back to 3.2v[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin 4 Gnd.[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin 5: same as pin2.[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]Pin 6: same as pin 3.[/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message:
It is trying to power on that is why you have unstable voltages. Check <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> with a scope to see if there are any pulses there, multimeter is too slow.
Must be liquid or drop, inspect closely.

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message:
I dont have a scope yet.
Is there an alternative move I can make?

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message: Nope, I have no idea how slow your multimeter is and if it is able to see the short pulses.

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message:
OK, while I try and track down a scope, maybe we can start checking from another angle.

[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is reading at 0, where does it come from?
<CHIP>U1800</CHIP> it seems, so why is it not sending anything?[/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message: It may also be pulsing......this is what these boards do if something is wrong in the power sequence.

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message:
[USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] could the unstable <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> be because it is trying to start up and something is tripping or failing?

If there was no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> it would just remain in an off state, but it appears that it is trying to progress along.

My thoughts being that it isn't <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> not creating the <SIGNAL>S4_L</SIGNAL> it is simply cycling before it get's that far.

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message: I really don't know. Check voltage to <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/1/2/3, <RESISTOR>R1915</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C2231</CAPACITOR>/32/33.

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message:
I'm getting;
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0.8v[/FONT][/COLOR]
[COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> = 0.44v

When the schematic specifically says <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> should be 1.25v.[/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: Yet another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Has a green light, but no power.
threads.message: You cannot get PPVCORE if there is no <SIGNAL>SLP_S4</SIGNAL>. What is going on here?
